commitResults.messageTitle: Added rename chatbot, greet and exit implementation
Add new task to list and display back
Add the ability to mark tasks as done or not done (both ways)
Add semi-automate the testing of Duke
Add support for deleting tasks from the list
Add the tasks in the hard disk automatically
commitResults.messageBody:
Save the tasks in the hard disk automatically whenever the task list
changes. Load the data from the hard disk when the chatbot starts up.

commitResults.messageTitle: Teach the chatbot how to understand dates and times
commitResults.messageBody:
Store deadline and event dates as java.time.LocalDateTime in
my task objects.

Accept dates in a format such as yyyy-mm-dd HH:mm format
(e.g., 2019-10-15 17:00) and print in a different format
such as MMM dd yyyy HH:mm e.g., (Oct 15 2019 17:00).

commitResults.messageTitle: Make the code more OOP and fix date time format
commitResults.messageBody:
Make the code more OOP by the creation of the following classes.

Ui: deals with interactions with the user.

Storage: deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks
in the file.

Parser: deals with making sense of the user command.

TaskList: contains the task list e.g., it has operations to
add/delete tasks in the list.

The codebase needs better organization, and introducing packages
will improve maintainability and structure.

Organize classes into packages according to their functionality and
purpose.

Using packages aligns with best practices for Java projects,
enhancing code readability and maintainability.

This change ensures a more structured and scalable project
architecture.

This project currently lacks a standardized build system, making it
difficult to manage dependencies and build processes consistently.

Introduce Gradle as the build tool for the project to provide a
well-organized and maintainable structure. This change facilitates
dependency management, build automation, and enhances the overall
project development experience.

Gradle is chosen for its flexibility, plugin ecosystem, and ease of use.
It ensures consistent builds across different environments and
simplifies the management of project dependencies.

This commit sets up the basic Gradle configuration.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add JUnit tests for Parser and TaskList classes
commitResults.messageBody:
The current situation lacks sufficient test coverage for the Parser
and TaskList classes, particularly for their non-trivial methods.

For the Parser class, JUnit tests have been introduced to cover
various scenarios and ensure the correctness of parsing methods.
This approach enhances the reliability of the Parser class,
making it more robust and resilient to different input formats.

For the TaskList class, comprehensive JUnit tests have been added
to cover key functionalities such as adding, deleting, marking, and
unmarking tasks. This testing approach ensures that the TaskList class
behaves correctly under different scenarios, catching potential bugs
and enhancing the stability of the application.

No other relevant information at this time.

JavaDoc comments are essential for providing
clear documentation about classes, methods, and other code elements.
They serve as a valuable resource for developers, enhancing code
understanding, and facilitating maintenance.

Added JavaDoc comments to all classes
and methods, ensuring that each comment follows the established
coding standards. The comments include relevant information about
the purpose, parameters, return values, and exceptions of the methods.

Following the established JavaDoc
conventions ensures consistency and readability. The comments
are concise, providing essential information without unnecessary
details. The goal is to improve code documentation and make it
easier for developers to understand and work with the codebase.

Developers are encouraged to maintain
the JavaDoc comments whenever they make changes to the code to
keep the documentation up-to-date.

Improve method names in ParserTest and TaskListTest
for clarity and consistency.

Refactor to align with coding standard.

commitResults.messageTitle: Give users a way to find a task by searching for a keyword
commitResults.messageBody:
Improve task search functionality

Users should have the ability to find a task by searching for a keyword.
This commit introduces enhancements to the search feature.

- Implement a method in the TaskList class to find tasks containing
a specified keyword.
- Update the Parser class to handle the "find" command and parse
the keyword.
- Enhance the UI to display matching tasks when the "find"
command is used.

This approach provides a more user-friendly experience,
allowing users to quickly locate tasks based on specific keywords.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add addTask when user enter todo, event or deadline
commitResults.messageBody: Forgot to add the line where task will be added to tasklist

commitResults.messageTitle: Use Checkstyle for Java code quality checks
commitResults.messageBody:
The current situation lacks consistent code quality checks, which
can lead to inconsistencies and potential bugs.

Integrate Checkstyle for enforcing coding standards and improving
code quality.

This approach ensures that all code follows the same style guidelines,
enhancing readability and maintainability.

Checkstyle configurations have been added to the project for consistent
code formatting and style checks.

The current command-line interface for the chatbot is not user-friendly
and lacks visual appeal, making it difficult for users to interact
with the chatbot effectively.

Implement a graphical user interface (GUI) for the chatbot to enhance
user experience and improve usability.

The GUI provides a more intuitive way for users to interact with the
chatbot by presenting the conversation in a visually appealing manner.
It allows users to easily input messages and view responses in a
structured format, enhancing the overall user experience.

This change aligns with the goal of improving user engagement and
satisfaction with the chatbot application.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor files from Duke to Denify
commitResults.messageBody:
Fixes naming inconsistency in project files

Rename all occurrences of "Duke" to "Denify" across the project files.

This change is necessary to maintain consistency and clarity in the
 project's naming conventions.

- Renamed classes, packages, and resources from "Duke" to "Denify"
for better coherence.
- Updated references and imports to reflect the new naming convention.

Additional context:
- Update imports, package names, and documentation accordingly
- Verify and test the functionality after renaming to ensure no
regressions occur

Assert statements are essential for enhancing code reliability and
facilitating debugging processes.

- Add assert statements to critical sections of the codebase to enforce
 expected conditions.
- Ensure that the application behaves as intended by validating inputs,
outputs, and intermediate states.

This approach is chosen because it allows for early detection of
potential issues during development and testing phases. Assertions
serve as a form of self-documentation, providing clarity on expected
behavior and assumptions made within the code.

Additional context:
- Review existing code to identify areas where assert statements
can be beneficially applied.
- Balance assert usage to avoid excessive overhead.
Use Assertions

Enhance readability and maintainability by updating variable to standard
naming conventions. This ensures consistency across the codebase
and improves code comprehension for developers.

Rename variables using descriptive nouns and verbs to accurately
represent their purpose and behavior. Follow established naming
conventions for better code organization and understanding.
Branch a code quality

commitResults.messageTitle: Ensure method/class header comments follow the format specified in the coding standard
commitResults.messageBody:
The current situation is that method/class header comments
do not consistently adhere to the specified format, leading to
inconsistency and potential confusion for developers.

To maintain code consistency and improve readability,
this commit ensures that all method/class header comments
follow the prescribed format, particularly focusing on the
 phrasing of the overview statement.

This is done to enforce uniformity across the codebase,
making it easier for developers to understand the purpose
and functionality of methods and classes at a glance.

No other relevant information at this time.

commitResults.messageTitle: Deal with duplicate items -- improve task addition handling
commitResults.messageBody:
This change is necessary to prevent the addition of duplicate tasks
to the task list. By checking for duplicates before adding a task, I
ensure data consistency and provide better user feedback.

- Modified the addTask method in the TaskList class to check for
duplicate tasks before adding.
- If a duplicate task is found, a DenifyException is thrown with
the message "Task already exists. Delete it to edit."

This approach is chosen to maintain the integrity of the task list
and provide clear guidance to users when attempting to add duplicate
tasks.

Adjusted font sizes, colors and crop display picture for better
readability and added GUI title.

This change is necessary to provide a more cohesive and aesthetically
pleasing user experience. The adjustments ensure that elements are
visually aligned and styled consistently throughout the application,
which enhances usability and reduces cognitive load for users.

By adjusting font sizes and colors, users can more easily navigate
and interact with the graphical user interface. Consistency in design
also helps to reinforce branding and improves overall user satisfaction.

To provide users with comprehensive documentation on how to use
the application.

Created a user guide file with detailed instructions and examples
for various features.

This approach ensures that users have access to clear and
concise guidance on using the application effectively.
